newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU view of Boeing deal not political - Van Miert.
newsitem.headline: EU view of Boeing deal not political - Van Miert.

text.p: EU Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert, reacting to statements in the United States, said on Thursday the analysis of the Boeing /McDonnell Douglas merger was based on facts and was not politically motivated.

He also welcomed the backing of the European Union's advisory committee on competition policy for the European Commission's position that the concessions offered by Boeing were not enough to meet EU antitrust concerns.
In a statement, Van Miert said he would not react to the verbal controversy the issue had created in political and business circles in the United States.
But he reiterated that the EU executive had handled the dossier strictly under the bloc's merger regulation, which bans the creation or strengthening of a dominant market position.

In Washington on Wednesday members of Congress denounced the EU stance as outrageous and ludicrous, and the Senate unanimously approved a measure condemning the European Union for its expected rejection of the merger.

Republican Senator Slade Gorton, from Boeing's home state of Washington, late on Wednesday introduced and won unanimous approval for an amendment to the $13.2 billion foreign aid appropriation for fiscal 1998, which starts in October.

"The sole true reason for the European Commission's criticism and imminent disapproval of the merger is to gain an unfair competitive advantage for Airbus, a government-owned aircraft manufacturer," Gorton said in a statement.
